captions.text: Good morning everyone

I've gathered you all today because you're
the greatest television writers ever!

And were gonna write the best TV show of all
time!
Yeah, I don't really do TV anymore...
Shut up! Okay ideas, ideas!
I say we give the audience what it wants.

META! Upon meta! Then more meta, plus meta!
Within meta!
Okay Dan, you're fired.
Oh man, not again!
I'll be back! I'll be back I tells ya!
Ideas!

Okay so, I say we get the audience really
emotionally invested...
Yeah...?
Make them fall in love with the characters...
Yeah..? Yeah??
And then we kill them all horribly!
Yes! Yes!!!
NO! lets cut off their dicks first!
No!!!
And then we'll bring them all back 17 times!
That's worse!
I don't understand this kidnapping business,

Couldn't you put out some peanuts? I'm not
saying cashews, peanuts! Is it really too much to ask?

Really? You only kidnapped two women? Women
can be kidnapped!

Yeah, umm... I'm with Larry on the whole culinary
business...
Honestly, I was expecting cake so...?
Blerg!
No catchphrases!
Meta!
Go away!!!
Let me kill him! Kill him!!!

Okay, but if were gonna kill him, let's set
it up on season 1 and only pay it off on season 8
so that only two people on Reddit will understand!
Really? Still no peanuts?
AHHHH!!! NOOO!!!
Really? She was an alien all along?
That's so lazy!
It didn't have anything to do with the plot!
I loved it!

and when reporters investigated, the story turned out to be false. She lied 
about the whole thing. She's never apologised to the guy for it.

comments.text:
Steven Moffat- the God of plot twists, kill offs, and not explaining stuff 
we want to be explained. (Do you just want to hear the theories?)
Russell T Davies- the God of crying and everything remotely sad...
and Torchwood.
I know we all blame Moffat for the sad stuff. But who wrote "Journey's End" 
or "Doomsday?" That was Russell. (And I am willing to put money on the 
table that he wrote "Angels Take Manhattan" as well. I've heard it's one of 
the saddest episodes in the series.)﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: Damian Freeman (TheExceeder)

comments.text:
+Damian Freeman i like his handling of sherlock as do many of his british 
and the amercian audience who download it abroad although i can see his 
handling of the doctor may be divisive to traditionalist


but to fair the doctor who franchise has always been somewhat light and 
occasionally cheesy writing with until recently low budget affect a la 
blake 7 and star trek
hence it has had smething of a cult following among adults much like star 
trek and its less well funded cousin babylon 5 had
it wasnt originally conceived for an adult auidence and only recently 
gained mainstream credibility
comments.author: epirus500

comments.text:
+Liuliwuyu G In a way Moffat is the Wheatley of Doctor Who - seems nice 
when you first meet him but you start noticing the flaws in his methodology 
as time progresses until you just want to oust him and put the previous guy 
back in even if they were trying to kill you.
comments.author: Damian Freeman (TheExceeder)

comments.text:
+Cecilia C I figured every major person involved was responsible in 
someway, after all they each have their own agenda. But Moffat at least 
acted as the leader of this production, and has insisted on some of the 
worst choices.

comments.text:

Can't blame Sherlock on Moffat alone, Gatiss was also responsible.
comments.author: Cecilia C

comments.text:

comments.author: Zoe Anne Kaw

comments.text:
+Cecilia C He has good point setting up short dramatic comedy or building 
upon recognizable, iconic figures. But these are not what I look for in an 
TV series, which is a stretched out media with long development periods. I 
guess Sherlock benefit from only having 3 episode every two years, it hides 
his weak points, which is no consistency, no accountability, no development 
and just no new tricks up his sleeves. Maybe he will be better off doing 
stand up-but again he is not the charismatic kind- so maybe writing for 
stand up?
comments.author: Liuliwuyu G

comments.text:
+Liuliwuyu G
Or realizing that Moffat had his good and bad points like most writers. 
It's kind of out there...I know.

wouldnt exist

comments.author: Tired Artist

comments.text:
+Tired Artist
Dude, the author of the comic got killed by the main villain, he proposed 
to one of the characters, then helped the main villain take control of the 
comic from him. Later, the main character becomes unbound to the canon of 
the story, leaves the entire comic, briefly enters a scene in his favorite 
movie, and beats up a prepubescent version of the main antagonist outside 
of the canon of the comic.

How does *ANYTHING* get more meta than that?
comments.author: PokemonTom09

comments.text:
+PokemonTom09
The meta upon meta one reminded me more of Gurren Lagann..
But the killing one and reviving them 17 times is pretty much Homestuck.
comments.author: Tired Artist

comments.text:
"Meta upon meta, then more meta, plus meta within meta"
"Let's set it up in season one then only pay it off in season eight" (have 
things set up early then not mention til near the end)

Yep, Homestuck

comments.author: Margarito Colocho

comments.text:
Self-referential, basically. So, if you're familiar with comics, imagine 
Deadpool. He's a guy constantly talking directly to the reader of the 
comic, and is obviously aware that he is just a character in a story.
